How hard is it to buy from you?

How difficult is it to complete a transaction? 

Customers don't have time or patience for effort when everything else in their lives is becoming more convenient. 

Remove effort.

The attention span of people dramatically decreases over time from using TikTok. But the same pattern is not seen on other social media platforms, such as Facebook and Instagram.

https://t.co/FvTR3mLXKf
Brain scans of college students showed that areas involved in addiction were highly activated in those who watched personalized videos, such as TikTok.

Your child’s brain won’t want to set aside a device that’s delivering entertainment. When you practice stopping, it strengthens those connections in the brain to allow you to stop next time.

But it's not just our children. 

It's also adults. It's called Neuroplasticity.
Neuroscientists have shown that “the dopamine rush of endless short videos” makes it hard for young viewers to switch their focus to slower-moving, teacher-guided activities

Other sources....

Emerging research suggests that watching short, fast-paced videos makes it harder for kids to sustain activities that don’t offer instant—and constant—gratification.

But it's not just kids...

Multi-tasking is being exposed as a myth, and new evidence-based research connects the proliferation of smartphones with distractibility in workplaces and schools contributing to more frequent errors, higher levels of stress, reduced cognitive ability, and lower productivity.

I still have to read LifeSCALE even though I wrote it to improve my routines + elevate my creativity, vision, and journey. With every new device, app, or digital process, I still work to keep my cognitive load, imagination, and center in balance.📱
#mentalhealth #digitalwellness

And that moment can manifest itself with a multitude of faces and effects, attention deficits, burnout, breakdown, broken relationships, sleep deprivation, low self-esteem, anxiety, stress, depression, and so many more health issues. 🥵

The thing that I still haven't figured out is how to help others recognize that their digital routines are hurting them and those who matter around them *before* the inevitable moment that changes everything aka the "uh oh" incident. 🤒😵‍💫

“Even when you’re not on screens, screens are in your head,” Rosen said.

Not only do we always carry a cognitive load 24/7, it rewires our brain for speed, multitasking, and more distractions. We lose focus, depth, and presence. We literally wire ourselves for a downward spiral.

The problem is far more pervasive now since 2020 + newer apps like #TikTok make #habitholes easier.

With LifeSCALE, I wanted us to take control of our digital lives vs our devices and habits controlling us. 

It's easy to spiral out of control without knowing it's a problem.

"What we’re finding is people are spending way more time on screens than previously reported or than they believe they are,” said Larry Rosen, professor emeritus of psychology at California State University, Dominguez Hills, to @WIRED. “It’s become somewhat of an #epidemic.”

Studies found that high levels of social media use are connected with an increased risk of symptoms of anxiety and depression.

It happened to me and many close to me.😶

After 2 years of research, I shared a journey toward a solution + balance here: https://t.co/bOilgX1PB5

Being observed by so many people appears to have significant psychological effects. There is now substantial evidence connecting people’s mental health and their online habits.🤳

https://t.co/i2DAvNDIGq

6/

48% of students predicted their qualifications would only be relevant for their chosen career path for five years or less after graduation.

1/3 want more career planning help, while 36% need wellbeing resources, mental health support, pastoral care, and financial aid. 

5/

69% of students who had a great onboarding also felt that their college offered a personalized experience tailored to their individual needs.

40% of students need more help managing their work-life balance.

4/

Just 2% of students who had a poor onboarding experience said they had a great college experience overall.

Students who had a great onboarding experience were 35x more likely to have a great university experience than those who didn’t. 

3/

Only a third of students report having great university experiences

Just 12% of students feel a strong sense of belonging at their institutions.

Just a third of students surveyed rated their onboarding experience highly.

2/

Also on Sunday, go to bed early. 🛌

If you feel sleepy 😪 the Sunday after the change to daylight saving time, take a short 15- to 20- minute nap in the early afternoon — not too close to bedtime.

Repeat.

On Saturday, set your clocks ahead one hour early in the evening, then go to bed at your normal bedtime. 🕐

On Sunday, spend some time outside in the early morning sunlight, which will help set that internal clock that regulates sleep and alertness. 🌞

(cont'd)

The sleep medicine academy recommends the following to minimize fatigue... 😴

Shift your bedtime 15 to 20 minutes earlier starting tonight.

Adjust the timing of daily routines to begin earlier giving your body new "time cues." 

(cont'd)

Changing the clock 🕛changes up our body's production of hormones, including melatonin, the night-time hormone that affects sleep; cortisol, the stress hormone; and serotonin, the "feel-good" hormone that helps keep depression and anxiety at bay.

The American Academy of Sleep Medicine has called for daylight saving time to end. ☀️

The American Heart Association issued its yearly reminder that incidents of heart disease and stroke go up at daylight saving time — a biological "clock shock" thus far unexplained.

Spotify CEO @eldsjal to employees in company town hall:

What's behind the #GreatResignation?

1: Motivations for work changed
2: Beliefs about what makes a “good job” diverged
3: Automation rehumanized work, making it more creative

5: Younger workers are increasingly overwhelmed

One more time for the people in the back…

“Technology will only work if it has people's trust." – Tim Cook, Apple

12 of 12

"Today it's [privacy] one of the primary issues in people's minds because people know that the web has become this surveillance tool...and that the building of detailed profiles on people has gone well beyond any kind of reasonable thing." – Tim Cook, Apple

11 of 12

Tim Cook's continued pressure on Facebook involves relatively combative language for a CEO to speak, which he says is needed. 

Source: https://t.co/vvxIUxLuZQ

10 of 12

When Apple's Tim Cook was asked if people's trust has been taken advantage of by tech firms, he responded, "In some cases the answer is undeniably yes. And I think it's incumbent on all of us to rebuild that trust."

9 of 12

“Facebook wouldn't be in this position at all if it had just responded by saying ‘yes, we have a large and popular right-wing news ecosystem that generates a lot of engagement.’ Instead, execs decided to try to fight data with other data.” – @kevinroose

8 of 12

In 2020, @kevinroose created @FacebooksTop10 to cast a light on (and attention to) the top-performing U.S. link posts. Every day, the majority of links were identified as disinformation without any action from Facebook. 

7 of 12

This week, it was reported that @Facebook shelved its content transparency report in Q1 fearing public criticism, as the most-viewed link suggested a doctor died due to a COVID-19 vaccine.

Source: https://t.co/26JyQ2eEcm

6 of 12

Tech has been a source of disinformation related to politics and the pandemic, compromising preventative measures and vaccines. Facebook and Twitter have come under fire for not doing enough to combat false information on their platforms.

Source: https://t.co/XfvfbKLhdH

5 of 12

In fact, Trust in the technology sector is rapidly declining around the world, according to the 2021 Edelman Trust Barometer. 

In the US, tech also saw the biggest decline in trust compared to other sectors like fashion, entertainment and retail.

4 of 12

"The risk of not doing that [thinking carefully about how tech is used] means that technology loses touch with the user,” said Apple’s Tim Cook. “Conspiracy theories or hate speech begins to drown everything else out. Technology will only work if it has people's trust."

3 of 12

"At Apple, when we make something, we make sure that we spend an enormous amount of time thinking carefully about how it will be used." – Tim Cook

2 of 12

Apple’s Tim Cook on the role of tech in a polarized and disinformed society…

"Technology doesn't want to be good. It doesn't want to be bad, it's neutral. And so it's in the hands of the inventor and the user as to whether it's used for good, or not used for good."

1 of 12

Ask yourself, what aspects of your pre- and pandemic life do you like and will miss when they stop?

Consider how you can integrate them into life as the world reopens.

To start your new life in a new world, all it takes is answering a few simple but profound questions. 

4/4

Ask yourself, what aspects of your pre-pandemic and lockdown life you're going to leave behind. Also consider too if you need to leave behind any relationships.

Start a list. Again, be honest with yourself. It's not meant to be easy.

3/4

Start with a 2-by-2 matrix and write "like" and "dislike" across the top and "pandemic" and "pre-pandemic" down the side. Reflect on what was working and not working before and during the pandemic. 

Confront who you really are. Commit to complete honesty and be specific.

2/4

THREAD: It's time to start preparing for a new and better normal. Ask yourself 3 questions before the "great re-opening" - 

1) Who were you really before the pandemic?
2) Who have you become during the pandemic?
3) Who do you want to become post-pandemic?

1/4

Sustainable products are becoming important to conscious Australian customers. They are seeking socially responsible companies.
Individual modes of transportation are on the rise vs public transport. 🚶🚲🚗

Australians will continue some at-home habits developed during the crisis, such as online fitness, use of wellness apps, telemedicine, remote learning, video chat, videoconferencing, online fitness...

Consumers have intensified their digital behavior including streaming, video chat, video conferencing, grocery and restaurant delivery, buying online for in-store pickup, curbside, remote learning, telemedicine...

80% of Australians are waiting for indicators beyond lifted restrictions before reengaging in out-of-home activities.

Crowds cause worry for consumers. This affects travel, events, transportation, gyms, entertainment, restaurants, salons, malls/stores...
In-store shopping is influenced by cleaning, sanitization, physical distancing, masks/barriers, and no-contact purchasing.

Australians are seeking better value, greater availability, and supporting local businesses.

Availability, prices, and value are key drivers for experimenting with new brands.

Digital is an important trigger for discovery with 60% of customers starting the journey via screens.

Loyalty and acquisition are in play with 57% having tried a new shopping behavior during #COVID19 with extremely high intentions of continuing these new behaviors. 

Different brands, stores/sites, digital shopping methods...

Though, spending on nonessentials is still below pre-#COVID19 levels, intent is rebounding in all categories. 📈

When they do spend money, they are becoming more and more digital (20-35% growth). Groceries is at the top of the list (43%)

Australians are looking for ways to save and they're becoming more mindful of how they spend their money when shopping. 🛒🛍️

And, more Australians are feeling careful about how they spend their money, and are cutting back on spending. 🏦

More than 1/4 of Australians are pessimistic about #COVID19 economic recovery. The highest since the onset of the pandemic.
😷

Designing with relationships as the ultimate goal helps us focus on the next human, not the next dollar. It lets us shift from transactions to trust.
We create a culture of compassion when we reward curiosity and attention to the experiences of others.

The 4 mindsets of relationship design:

1. Compassion mindset—to lead with strengthening connection

2. Courage mindset—to push ourselves to be vulnerable

3. Intention mindset—to engage with clear purpose

4. Reciprocity mindset—to exchange value in service of longevity

Use design to strengthen employee relationships: 

1. Increase collaboration across teams and departments by solving problems together.

2. Do research and use design tools to better understand the employee journey.

3. Create a safe environment for creative risk-taking.

"Those who can make you believe absurdities can make you commit atrocities." – Voltaire

If you're human, you're biased. But when your bias is intentionally stoked, lies and disinformation look a lot like facts, and truth looks a lot like fake news. Bias becomes kindling. Shared bias becomes community. All it takes is a spark. When ignited, actions feel righteous.🔥

The solution isn't blame or misdirection. It's understanding that the digital radicalization seen with ISIS is happening in the U.S. (and around the world) at speed+scale...in the dark and in broad daylight. It's profitable for many. It's also a matter of national security.

A simple exercise in digital forensics would connect faces to profiles, groups + comments. For weeks, Facebook, Reddit, Parler were teeming with discoverable details + post-chaos gloating.
